author: By Ben Shpigel
title: How the Bengals Beat Kansas City to Advance to the Super Bowl
description: With a calm that belied their underdog status, the Bengals intercepted Patrick Mahomes and completed a field-goal drive in overtime to end Kansas City’s streak of Super Bowl appearances.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Over the last three decades or so, the Cincinnati Bengals have dabbled in wretched football and entertaining football, tedious football and effective football, but not until this postseason had they managed to play the brand of football they desired most.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, Maggie Jones, John Woo and Elisheba Ittoop
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Joys (and Challenges) of Sex After 70’
description: Sex can drop off in our final decades. But for those who keep going, it can be the best of their lives.
content: Today, Maggie Jones explores the overlooked topic of geriatric sex. Profiling older couples for whom it is still important, she considers the obstacles and joys of having sex over the age of 70, and the way society has begun to talk more openly about it in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Why Churches Should Drop Their Online Services
description: In-person church is as essential as in-person school.
content: Over the past two years a refrain has become common in churches and other religious communities: “Join us in person or online.” I was a big proponent of that “or online” part. In March of 2020, we knew little about the new disease spreading rapidly around the world but we knew it was deadly, especially for the elderly. My church was one of the first in our city to forgo meeting in person and switch to an online format, and I encouraged other churches to do the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Bitterness From Supreme Court Fights Hangs Over Coming Nomination
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 30, 2022.
content: “I really think it would be harmful to the country to have a repeat of what we saw with the last two nominees being so narrowly confirmed. I just don’t think that is good for the country, nor the court.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Winter Storm, Russia, N.F.L.: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Mugler, Remembered by His Crowd
description: The designer, who died on Jan. 23, simply knew what he wanted, and how he wanted it.
content: Manfred Thierry Mugler, the French designer who died Jan. 23 at the age of 73, was nothing if not exacting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Twenty Years of Sub-Four-Minute Miles
description: Nick Willis ran a mile in under four minutes for the 20th straight year. It set off one of the more remarkable celebrations for a ninth-place finish.
content: Nick Willis knew he had a chance with one lap, or 200 meters, remaining in the Wanamaker Mile at the Millrose Games in New York City on Saturday afternoon. He saw that his split time was within range of his goal, if only he could find that gear for his finishing kick. But that gear, the familiar one that had helped drive him to two Olympic medals in the men’s 1,500 meters during his decorated career?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘The Collision’ and ‘The Martyrdom’ Review: A Nun Ahead of Her Time
description: A classic text by the 10th-century Saxon nun Hrotsvitha of Gandersheim inspires two new plays being performed as a double bill at 59E59 Theaters.
content: Three nuns hard at work at their convent look up to discover that the sky is falling …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 31, 2022
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Manchester United Bars Mason Greenwood After Abuse Accusation
description: A woman accused the young English forward of assaulting her in a post on Instagram. The team said he would not play or train “until further notice.”
content: Manchester United said it had suspended its young forward Mason Greenwood and would bar him from playing matches or even training with his teammates after he was accused by a woman on Sunday of assaulting her. The woman made the claim in a post on her personal social media account that included images, video and an audio recording.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: England extends vaccines to vulnerable children ages 5 to 11.
description: Around half a million children in England will become eligible for a first dose of a coronavirus shot on Monday.
content: Around half a million children in England will become eligible for a first dose of a coronavirus shot on Monday, as the National Health Service extends its vaccine rollout to children ages 5 to 11 who are considered most at risk of contracting the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: When All-White Was All Right
description: “Only when we disentangle the concepts of whiteness and maleness from the concept of power can we see the damage the association has done.”
content: Nominating Supreme Court justices has always been about identity and politics. It’s just that for nearly the first two centuries of the court’s existence, the only people considered for inclusion were white men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Obscure but Crucial Commodity Fuels Geopolitical Tussle in Eastern Europe
description: Lithuanian efforts to stop potash, a key fertilizer ingredient, from Belarus from crossing its territory to punish the country’s authoritarian leader may play into Russia’s hands.
content: KLAIPEDA, Lithuania — For nearly two decades, long freight trains laden with reddish-brown grit have rumbled into Lithuania’s main port on the Baltic Sea, providing an economic lifeline for Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the autocratic president of neighboring Belarus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Rafael Nadal Wins the Australian Open, His 21st Grand Slam Title
description: Novak Djokovic overshadowed the first Grand Slam of the year before it began, but Nadal pulled off an epic comeback over Daniil Medvedev that broke his tie with Djokovic and Roger Federer in men’s singles major career victories.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Spanish tennis star Rafael Nadal shook his head, as if in disbelief. Then he moved to the net to shake the hand of his opponent, Daniil Medvedev, and it was then that it seemed to sink in. Nadal stood alone in the record book with 21 career Grand Slam men’s singles titles, one more than his rivals Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Checkout Lines
description: Eric Bornstein’s puzzle heads for the hills.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations and welcome back to the constructor of this puzzle, Eric Bornstein, who is making his ninth appearance in the New York Times Crossword today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: How the Rams Beat the 49ers to Advance to the Super Bowl
description: Los Angeles’s high-profile roster additions provided sparks, but the homegrown talents Aaron Donald and Cooper Kupp provided crucial plays to win the N.F.C. championship.
content: INGLEWOOD, Calif. — The N.F.C. championship game displayed two different teams, two different fan bases and two different strategies for building a roster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang and Keith Bradsher
title: Living by the Code: In China, Covid-Era Controls May Outlast the Virus
description: The country has instituted a wide range of high-tech controls on society as part of a mostly successful effort to stop the virus. The consequences may endure.
content: The police had warned Xie Yang, a human rights lawyer, not to go to Shanghai to visit the mother of a dissident. He went to the airport anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
title: U.S. Allies Retake Control of Prison in Syria, Subduing ISIS Fighters
description: The fighting was the most intense urban warfare involving American troops in Iraq and Syria since the fall of the Islamic State.
content: HASAKA, Syria — Kurdish-led forces regained full control of a prison in northeastern Syria on Sunday after a battle which spread to surrounding neighborhoods in the most intense urban combat involving American soldiers in Iraq or Syria since the self-declared ISIS caliphate fell in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: Rolling With Wee Man, and His Fans
description: Reporting a magazine profile, a reporter learned a lot about the “Jackass” star, and found a passion for the show hidden among her peers.
content: I was five years into dating my now-husband when I discovered that the person I had spent five years dating had more to say about the early 2000s MTV show “Jackass” than any other topic. He possessed an encyclopedic knowledge of its stunts and pranks. I recall the moment the truth emerged: at the end of the annual Christmas party I host — a festivity that consumes 90 percent of my effort in a calendar year (the remaining 10 percent being parceled out to my job, personal relationships and health) — when it was time for everyone to go home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: The Hard-Line Russian Advisers Who Have Putin’s Ear
description: Three reactionary security officials dedicated to “traditional values” and restoring Soviet glory will figure prominently in the decision whether to invade Ukraine.
content: MOSCOW — The West is legalizing marriage between people and animals. Ukraine’s leaders are as bad as Hitler, and the country’s nationalists are “nonhumans.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea’s Latest Missile Test Appears to Be Its Boldest in Years
description: Flight data indicates that the launch on Sunday was the North’s most powerful since 2017. South Korean analysts expect further escalations from Kim Jong-un.
content: SEOUL — North Korea on Sunday carried out its boldest ballistic missile test in years, raising the stakes in a flurry of launches that analysts said were meant to put pressure on President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin and Giulia Heyward
title: ‘It’s Just Stressful’: Students Feel the Weight of Pandemic Uncertainty
description: The pandemic has changed children. Some can’t shake that feeling of instability. Others are taking on adult responsibilities. And anxiety is all around.
content: After months of remote learning, a year of in-person-but-not-quite-stable hybrid school and a fall semester that was just beginning to feel kind of normal, Kyla Chester-Hopkins, a high school junior in Milwaukee, learned that she had Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘One Woman Pulled Out a Key That Looked Just Right’
description: A luggage problem, an exchange at the Asia Society and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.,’ Biden Hopes That Memes Can Help the Crisis in Ukraine
description: This weekend’s episode, hosted by Willem Dafoe, featured music from Katy Perry and a welcome guest appearance by Peyton Manning.
content: This weekend’s opening sketch found James Austin Johnson as President Biden in the White House, being warned by a team of advisers about the increasingly tense situation in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Inflation and Deficits Don’t Dim the Appeal of U.S. Bonds
description: Treasury rates remain strikingly low, partly because of the safety government debt offers corporations and retirees. Whether that endures is crucial to federal spending.
content: Markets have been in upheaval. The Federal Reserve is taking steps to cool off the economy, as questions loom about the course of the recovery. And headlines are proclaiming that government bond yields are near two-year highs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: U.S. Floats Russian Sanctions
description: Also, the defeat of ISIS fighters in Syria and China’s pandemic surveillance state.
content: The most punishing sanctions that President Biden has threatened in an effort to deter an invasion of Ukraine could devastate the Russian economy. Analysts predict a stock market crash and other forms of financial panic that would inflict pain on Russia’s people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Campaigning to Oversee Elections, While Denying the Last One
description: Brazenly partisan candidates who insist that Donald Trump won the 2020 election are transforming races for the once-obscure office of secretary of state.
content: PHOENIX — Nearly two dozen Republicans who have publicly questioned or disputed the results of the 2020 election are running for secretary of state across the country, in some cases after being directly encouraged by allies of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jeremiah Stamler, Who Found Ways to Curb Heart Disease, Dies at 102
description: He was at the forefront of studies that found links between salt, diet and other risk factors and cardiovascular ailments.
content: Jeremiah Stamler, an indefatigable cardiovascular researcher who was at the forefront of studies that identified risk factors for heart disease and ways to prevent it, died on Wednesday at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: ‘There’s Nothing Quite as Distressing as This Piece’
description: The pianist Paul Lewis picks his favorite page of Brahms’s late solos, a work of “abject anguish.”
content: The British pianist Paul Lewis has made his name primarily in the music of the late 18th and early 19th centuries. His breakthrough on recordings came with the sensitive cycle of Beethoven sonatas he set down for the label Harmonia Mundi in the late 2000s. He followed that with a Schubert survey that remains a prime recommendation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: University Mistakenly Tells 5,500 Students They Won Huge Scholarships
description: Oakland University in Michigan said “human error” was to blame for the incorrect emails. It was the second university in the state this month to make such a mistake.
content: Carnell Poindexter looked at the subject line of the email — “Congratulations!” — and opened it immediately while in a debate class at his high school in West Bloomfield, Mich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: 4.1-Magnitude Earthquake Rattles Parts of California
description: Experts said that the earthquake, which was felt in Southern California, including San Diego and Riverside Counties, was “not a big deal,” but it did prompt lots of online chatter.
content: Sandra Herrera was getting dressed on Sunday morning when the ground started shaking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: Britain Toughens Stance on Russia, as Russia Presses NATO for Assurances
description: Britain moved to broaden the range of sanctions available if Russia invades Ukraine, as Moscow sent an “urgent demand” to NATO to clarify its stance.
content: LONDON — British lawmakers will be asked to consider legislation this week that would let ministers impose a wider range of sanctions against Russia should it move against Ukraine, the British foreign secretary said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gray Beltran
title: The Week in Business: Higher Interest Rates Are Coming
description: Inflation is high. The markets are volatile. Economic growth in the world’s two biggest economies is expected to slow. And the Winter Olympics begin.
content: After nearly two years of near-zero interest rates, the Federal Reserve signaled that it would probably raise them in March. Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, said officials no longer thought that America’s rapidly healing economy needed so much support, given that inflation is running far above policymakers’ target and the tight labor market. By making it more expensive to borrow money to buy a house or car, the Fed hopes the higher interest rates will cool demand and eventually help rein in inflation. The Fed’s preferred measure of inflation, the personal consumption expenditures index, was 5.8 percent in December, the fastest pace since 1982 and one that could be disastrous for the political prospects of President Biden and his fellow Democrats in the November midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: N.Y.C. is offering free home delivery of Covid antiviral pills, though supply is limited.
description: The pills, which require a prescription, are prioritized for those who test positive for the coronavirus and are at higher risk for severe illness.
content: New York City officials said Sunday that they were launching a program for residents to get antiviral Covid pills delivered directly to their homes for free, though supplies of the drugs remained limited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: ‘Stealth’ Variant No Cause for Alarm, but Could Slow Case Decline
description: A mutated version of the Omicron variant could slow the steep decline in cases, but it is not likely to change the overall course of the pandemic, scientists said.
content: In recent days, headlines about a “stealth” Omicron variant have conjured the notion that a villainous new form of the coronavirus is secretly creating a disastrous new wave of Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Canada Beats U.S., Cementing a Soccer Power Shift
description: The victory in a World Cup qualifier moved Canada to the cusp of its first World Cup berth since 1986, and reasserted its sudden dominance in North America.
content: HAMILTON, Canada — If it wasn’t already clear which country in North and Central America and the Caribbean had the best soccer team during this World Cup qualifying cycle, Canada provided another resounding argument for its primacy on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Book Ban Efforts Spread Across the U.S.
description: Challenges to books about sexual and racial identity are nothing new in American schools, but the tactics and politicization are.
content: In Wyoming, a county prosecutor’s office considered charges against library employees for stocking books like “Sex Is a Funny Word” and “This Book Is Gay.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Charlie Savage
title: For Ketanji Brown Jackson, View of Criminal Justice Was Shaped by Family
description: The story of an uncle’s cocaine conviction formed only part of Judge Jackson’s understanding of the system’s complexities. She is now seen as a contender to be President Biden’s Supreme Court pick.
content: MIAMI — Ketanji Brown Jackson does not much talk about it, but when she was a college freshman, an uncle was sentenced to life in prison — a Black man, like so many others, handed a severe punishment during the war-on-drugs era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine McGloin
title: Over 30 inches of snow has fallen in parts of Massachusetts, with power outages along the coast.
description: Blowing snow and “continued whiteout” conditions were forecast to persist until Sunday morning, officials said.
content: As much as 30 inches of snow had fallen in some parts of Massachusetts by early Saturday evening, Gov. Charlie Baker said at a news conference, while Boston had seen about two feet — nearly a record — with another two to four inches expected before the snow tapers off tonight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: Guns, Race, Abortion: Jennifer Haigh’s New Novel Humanizes Hot-Button Topics
description: Haigh’s latest book, “Mercy Street,” is set at a women’s clinic in Boston where the threat of violence is pervasive.
content: Has Jennifer Haigh’s moment arrived? For years Haigh has been peering deep into the heart of lost America, sketching characters whose interests are at cross-purposes but whose deep-seated deprivation binds them together. She’s been a superb unsung novelist hovering just under the radar. And her 2016 “Heat and Light,” torpedoed by its nominal subject and unsexy title, was a small-town epic on the order of Richard Russo’s “Empire Falls.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Martin
title: How Do You Respond When an Anti-Vaxxer Dies of Covid?
description: Don’t give in to schadenfreude. It warps the soul.
content: In the earliest days of the pandemic in New York City, I would often pass the refrigerated morgue trucks parked outside Mount Sinai Hospital, just a block from my Jesuit community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Berg, Melina Delkic, Patrick Cassidy, Catherine McGloin and Chantee Lans
title: In Icy Conditions, the Northeast Starts Digging Out
description: With snowplows and shovels, parts of Massachusetts and New York were clearing away piles of snow amid frigid wind chills.
content: STOUGHTON, Mass. — Twenty miles south of Boston, homeowners took to their driveways on Sunday morning with shovels, snowblowers and a little civic pride. Excavating cars that could hardly be seen under mountainous piles of dense snow, Stoughton residents faced the chilly task of digging out from a record-breaking winter storm, but at least they had some bragging rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Emily Cochrane
title: Trump Says He Would Consider Pardons for Jan. 6 Defendants if Elected
description: In a speech in Texas, the former president also urged supporters to stage protests if prosecutors in Atlanta and New York took action against him.
content: CONROE, Texas — Donald J. Trump said on Saturday that if elected to a new term as president, he would consider pardoning those prosecuted for attacking the United States Capitol on Jan. 6 last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Spotify Responds to Complaints About Covid Misinformation
description: After Neil Young and Joni Mitchell removed their music from the streaming service, its chief executive wrote, “it is important to me that we don’t take on the position of being content censor.”
content: The chief executive of Spotify responded on Sunday to growing complaints from musicians and listeners over the role of Joe Rogan, the streaming service’s star podcaster, in spreading what has been widely criticized as misinformation about the coronavirus. Last week, Neil Young and Joni Mitchell — two musical icons whose cultural influence is far greater than their streaming numbers — removed their music from Spotify to protest the platform’s support of Rogan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amanda Gorman’s Message to the World
description: Responses to the inaugural poet. Also: Teaching during Omicron; considering secession; America’s long game; a national ID card; reasons to be vegan.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Yewande Komolafe has all the restorative broths and teas you need right now.
content: Good morning. This is the time of year for some of us when, if you’re not careful, you can find yourself relearning the concept of being chilled to the bone. Linger too long on the sidewalk talking with a neighbor, or dash to the bodega in sweats and no hat? It can leave you feeling like human permafrost. That’s a hard state to alter.
source.name: The New York Times
